00007 """Utility functions for Windows builds.
00008 
00009 These functions are executed via gyp-win-tool when using the ninja generator.
00010 """
00011 
00012 import os
00013 import re
00014 import shutil
00015 import subprocess
00016 import stat
00017 import string
00018 import sys
00019 
00020 BASE_DIR = os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))
00021 
00022 # A regex matching an argument corresponding to the output filename passed to
00023 # link.exe.
00024 _LINK_EXE_OUT_ARG = re.compile('/OUT:(?P<out>.+)$', re.IGNORECASE)
00025 
00026 def main(args):
00027   executor = WinTool()
00028   exit_code = executor.Dispatch(args)
00029   if exit_code is not None:
00030     sys.exit(exit_code)
00031 
00032 
00033 class WinTool(object):
00034   """This class performs all the Windows tooling steps. The methods can either
00035   be executed directly, or dispatched from an argument list."""
00036 
00037   def _UseSeparateMspdbsrv(self, env, args):
00038     """Allows to use a unique instance of mspdbsrv.exe per linker instead of a
00039     shared one."""
00040     if len(args) < 1:
00041       raise Exception("Not enough arguments")
00042 
00043     if args[0] != 'link.exe':
00044       return
00045 
00046     # Use the output filename passed to the linker to generate an endpoint name
00047     # for mspdbsrv.exe.
00048     endpoint_name = None
00049     for arg in args:
00050       m = _LINK_EXE_OUT_ARG.match(arg)
00051       if m:
00052         endpoint_name = re.sub(r'\W+', '',
00053             '%s_%d' % (m.group('out'), os.getpid()))
00054         break
00055 
00056     if endpoint_name is None:
00057       return
00058 
00059     # Adds the appropriate environment variable. This will be read by link.exe
00060     # to know which instance of mspdbsrv.exe it should connect to (if it's
00061     # not set then the default endpoint is used).
00062     env['_MSPDBSRV_ENDPOINT_'] = endpoint_name
00063 
00064   def Dispatch(self, args):
00065     """Dispatches a string command to a method."""
00066     if len(args) < 1:
00067       raise Exception("Not enough arguments")
00068 
00069     method = "Exec%s" % self._CommandifyName(args[0])
00070     return getattr(self, method)(*args[1:])
00071 
00072   def _CommandifyName(self, name_string):
00073     """Transforms a tool name like recursive-mirror to RecursiveMirror."""
00074     return name_string.title().replace('-', '')
00075 
00076   def _GetEnv(self, arch):
00077     """Gets the saved environment from a file for a given architecture."""
00078     # The environment is saved as an "environment block" (see CreateProcess
00079     # and msvs_emulation for details). We convert to a dict here.
00080     # Drop last 2 NULs, one for list terminator, one for trailing vs. separator.
00081     pairs = open(arch).read()[:-2].split('\0')
00082     kvs = [item.split('=', 1) for item in pairs]
00083     return dict(kvs)
00084 
00085   def ExecStamp(self, path):
00086     """Simple stamp command."""
00087     open(path, 'w').close()
00088 
00089   def ExecRecursiveMirror(self, source, dest):
00090     """Emulation of rm -rf out && cp -af in out."""
00091     if os.path.exists(dest):
00092       if os.path.isdir(dest):
00093         def _on_error(fn, path, excinfo):
00094           # The operation failed, possibly because the file is set to
00095           # read-only. If that's why, make it writable and try the op again.
00096           if not os.access(path, os.W_OK):
00097             os.chmod(path, stat.S_IWRITE)
00098           fn(path)
00099         shutil.rmtree(dest, onerror=_on_error)
00100       else:
00101         if not os.access(dest, os.W_OK):
00102           # Attempt to make the file writable before deleting it.
00103           os.chmod(dest, stat.S_IWRITE)
00104         os.unlink(dest)
00105 
00106     if os.path.isdir(source):
00107       shutil.copytree(source, dest)
00108     else:
00109       shutil.copy2(source, dest)
00110 
00111   def ExecLinkWrapper(self, arch, use_separate_mspdbsrv, *args):
00112     """Filter diagnostic output from link that looks like:
00113     '   Creating library ui.dll.lib and object ui.dll.exp'
00114     This happens when there are exports from the dll or exe.
00115     """
00116     env = self._GetEnv(arch)
00117     if use_separate_mspdbsrv == 'True':
00118       self._UseSeparateMspdbsrv(env, args)
00119     link = subprocess.Popen([args[0].replace('/', '\\')] + list(args[1:]),
00120                             shell=True,
00121                             env=env,
00122                             stdout=subprocess.PIPE,
00123                             stderr=subprocess.STDOUT)
00124     out, _ = link.communicate()
00125     for line in out.splitlines():
00126       if not line.startswith('   Creating library '):
00127         print line
00128     return link.returncode
00129 
00130   def ExecLinkWithManifests(self, arch, embed_manifest, out, ldcmd, resname,
00131                             mt, rc, intermediate_manifest, *manifests):
00132     """A wrapper for handling creating a manifest resource and then executing
00133     a link command."""
00134     # The 'normal' way to do manifests is to have link generate a manifest
00135     # based on gathering dependencies from the object files, then merge that
00136     # manifest with other manifests supplied as sources, convert the merged
00137     # manifest to a resource, and then *relink*, including the compiled
00138     # version of the manifest resource. This breaks incremental linking, and
00139     # is generally overly complicated. Instead, we merge all the manifests
00140     # provided (along with one that includes what would normally be in the
00141     # linker-generated one, see msvs_emulation.py), and include that into the
00142     # first and only link. We still tell link to generate a manifest, but we
00143     # only use that to assert that our simpler process did not miss anything.
00144     variables = {
00145       'python': sys.executable,
00146       'arch': arch,
00147       'out': out,
00148       'ldcmd': ldcmd,
00149       'resname': resname,
00150       'mt': mt,
00151       'rc': rc,
00152       'intermediate_manifest': intermediate_manifest,
00153       'manifests': ' '.join(manifests),
00154     }
00155     add_to_ld = ''
00156     if manifests:
00157       subprocess.check_call(
00158           '%(python)s gyp-win-tool manifest-wrapper %(arch)s %(mt)s -nologo '
00159           '-manifest %(manifests)s -out:%(out)s.manifest' % variables)
00160       if embed_manifest == 'True':
00161         subprocess.check_call(
00162             '%(python)s gyp-win-tool manifest-to-rc %(arch)s %(out)s.manifest'
00163           ' %(out)s.manifest.rc %(resname)s' % variables)
00164         subprocess.check_call(
00165             '%(python)s gyp-win-tool rc-wrapper %(arch)s %(rc)s '
00166             '%(out)s.manifest.rc' % variables)
00167         add_to_ld = ' %(out)s.manifest.res' % variables
00168     subprocess.check_call(ldcmd + add_to_ld)
00169 
00170     # Run mt.exe on the theoretically complete manifest we generated, merging
00171     # it with the one the linker generated to confirm that the linker
00172     # generated one does not add anything. This is strictly unnecessary for
00173     # correctness, it's only to verify that e.g. /MANIFESTDEPENDENCY was not
00174     # used in a #pragma comment.
00175     if manifests:
00176       # Merge the intermediate one with ours to .assert.manifest, then check
00177       # that .assert.manifest is identical to ours.
00178       subprocess.check_call(
00179           '%(python)s gyp-win-tool manifest-wrapper %(arch)s %(mt)s -nologo '
00180           '-manifest %(out)s.manifest %(intermediate_manifest)s '
00181           '-out:%(out)s.assert.manifest' % variables)
00182       assert_manifest = '%(out)s.assert.manifest' % variables
00183       our_manifest = '%(out)s.manifest' % variables
00184       # Load and normalize the manifests. mt.exe sometimes removes whitespace,
00185       # and sometimes doesn't unfortunately.
00186       with open(our_manifest, 'rb') as our_f:
00187         with open(assert_manifest, 'rb') as assert_f:
00188           our_data = our_f.read().translate(None, string.whitespace)
00189           assert_data = assert_f.read().translate(None, string.whitespace)
00190       if our_data != assert_data:
00191         os.unlink(out)
00192         def dump(filename):
00193           sys.stderr.write('%s\n-----\n' % filename)
00194           with open(filename, 'rb') as f:
00195             sys.stderr.write(f.read() + '\n-----\n')
00196         dump(intermediate_manifest)
00197         dump(our_manifest)
00198         dump(assert_manifest)
00199         sys.stderr.write(
00200             'Linker generated manifest "%s" added to final manifest "%s" '
00201             '(result in "%s"). '
00202             'Were /MANIFEST switches used in #pragma statements? ' % (
00203               intermediate_manifest, our_manifest, assert_manifest))
00204         return 1
00205 
00206   def ExecManifestWrapper(self, arch, *args):
00207     """Run manifest tool with environment set. Strip out undesirable warning
00208     (some XML blocks are recognized by the OS loader, but not the manifest
00209     tool)."""
00210     env = self._GetEnv(arch)
00211     popen = subprocess.Popen(args, shell=True, env=env,
00212                              stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.STDOUT)
00213     out, _ = popen.communicate()
00214     for line in out.splitlines():
00215       if line and 'manifest authoring warning 81010002' not in line:
00216         print line
00217     return popen.returncode
00218 
00219   def ExecManifestToRc(self, arch, *args):
00220     """Creates a resource file pointing a SxS assembly manifest.
00221     |args| is tuple containing path to resource file, path to manifest file
00222     and resource name which can be "1" (for executables) or "2" (for DLLs)."""
00223     manifest_path, resource_path, resource_name = args
00224     with open(resource_path, 'wb') as output:
00225       output.write('#include <windows.h>\n%s RT_MANIFEST "%s"' % (
00226         resource_name,
00227         os.path.abspath(manifest_path).replace('\\', '/')))
00228 
00229   def ExecMidlWrapper(self, arch, outdir, tlb, h, dlldata, iid, proxy, idl,
00230                       *flags):
00231     """Filter noisy filenames output from MIDL compile step that isn't
00232     quietable via command line flags.
00233     """
00234     args = ['midl', '/nologo'] + list(flags) + [
00235         '/out', outdir,
00236         '/tlb', tlb,
00237         '/h', h,
00238         '/dlldata', dlldata,
00239         '/iid', iid,
00240         '/proxy', proxy,
00241         idl]
00242     env = self._GetEnv(arch)
00243     popen = subprocess.Popen(args, shell=True, env=env,
00244                              stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.STDOUT)
00245     out, _ = popen.communicate()
00246     # Filter junk out of stdout, and write filtered versions. Output we want
00247     # to filter is pairs of lines that look like this:
00248     # Processing C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\...\include\objidl.idl
00249     # objidl.idl
00250     lines = out.splitlines()
00251     prefixes = ('Processing ', '64 bit Processing ')
00252     processing = set(os.path.basename(x)
00253                      for x in lines if x.startswith(prefixes))
00254     for line in lines:
00255       if not line.startswith(prefixes) and line not in processing:
00256         print line
00257     return popen.returncode
00258 
00259   def ExecAsmWrapper(self, arch, *args):
00260     """Filter logo banner from invocations of asm.exe."""
00261     env = self._GetEnv(arch)
00262     popen = subprocess.Popen(args, shell=True, env=env,
00263                              stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.STDOUT)
00264     out, _ = popen.communicate()
00265     for line in out.splitlines():
00266       if (not line.startswith('Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation') and
00267           not line.startswith('Microsoft (R) Macro Assembler') and
00268           not line.startswith(' Assembling: ') and
00269           line):
00270         print line
00271     return popen.returncode
00272 
00273   def ExecRcWrapper(self, arch, *args):
00274     """Filter logo banner from invocations of rc.exe. Older versions of RC
00275     don't support the /nologo flag."""
00276     env = self._GetEnv(arch)
00277     popen = subprocess.Popen(args, shell=True, env=env,
00278                              stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.STDOUT)
00279     out, _ = popen.communicate()
00280     for line in out.splitlines():
00281       if (not line.startswith('Microsoft (R) Windows (R) Resource Compiler') and
00282           not line.startswith('Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation') and
00283           line):
00284         print line
00285     return popen.returncode

00287   def ExecActionWrapper(self, arch, rspfile, *dir):
00288     """Runs an action command line from a response file using the environment
00289     for |arch|. If |dir| is supplied, use that as the working directory."""
00290     env = self._GetEnv(arch)
00291     # TODO(scottmg): This is a temporary hack to get some specific variables
00292     # through to actions that are set after gyp-time. http://crbug.com/333738.
00293     for k, v in os.environ.iteritems():
00294       if k not in env:
00295         env[k] = v
00296     args = open(rspfile).read()
00297     dir = dir[0] if dir else None
00298     return subprocess.call(args, shell=True, env=env, cwd=dir)
00299 
00300   def ExecClCompile(self, project_dir, selected_files):
00301     """Executed by msvs-ninja projects when the 'ClCompile' target is used to
00302     build selected C/C++ files."""
00303     project_dir = os.path.relpath(project_dir, BASE_DIR)
00304     selected_files = selected_files.split(';')
00305     ninja_targets = [os.path.join(project_dir, filename) + '^^'
00306         for filename in selected_files]
00307     cmd = ['ninja.exe']
00308     cmd.extend(ninja_targets)
00309     return subprocess.call(cmd, shell=True, cwd=BASE_DIR)
00310 
00311 if __name__ == '__main__':
00312   sys.exit(main(sys.argv[1:]))
